awd_titl_txt: CRII: RI: Embedded and Continuous Shape Morphing using Twisted-and-Coiled Artificial Muscle
awd_abstract_narration:
Many animals have the ability to locomote in different environments, such as on land, in the water, and in the air.  Developing biologically inspired robots with similar abilities would open up many new types of applications for robotics. Towards this goal, this research investigates a novel shape morphing scheme that can autonomously modify the shape of a structure, such as by changing legs to flippers. With shape morphing capabilities, robots can leverage varying shapes from the same structure for locomotion in different environments, which can drastically reduce the robot's costs while dramatically improving their performance. The approach can enable a structure to precisely morph into a three-dimensional shape without using bulky external sensors and actuators, making it suitable for various applications such as morphing wings, multimodal robots, programmable matter, foldable robots, etc. The project will also broadly impact STEM students of all ages through outreach to K-12 students, enhancement of existing curriculum with research-inspired projects, and promotion of undergraduate research.

The new shape morphing scheme is accomplished by embedding a novel twisted-and-coiled actuator (TCA) into soft materials, together with a thermoplastic material with temperature-dependent stiffness.  With the proposed scheme, this project aims to accomplish embedded and continuous shape morphing through closed-loop shape control enabled by the TCA's dual actuation and sensing capabilities. To do this, physics-based models will be first established to relate a desired shape of a structure to the embedded TCA's electrical resistance. Then, closed-loop shape control can be accomplished by controlling the TCA's resistance to a desired value. Finally, the proposed shape morphing scheme is applied to a miniature amphibious robot that can swim in water with straight legs and travel on ground by morphing the legs into a curved shape.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As vividly pictured in the 2018 Transformers film, the Bumblebee can easily transform from a car into a legged robot and back. Film fantasies aside, such marvelous transformations can rarely be realized by today's robotic systems. Most existing robots have mechanical structures (legs, body shapes) that are generally fixed after a robot is built. Can we morph a robot's shape on the fly for a new function without rebuilding it? Answering this question will be instrumental in developing transformable robots for different tasks (e.g., wheeling to travel on flat ground at a fast speed, legged motion for rough terrains, similar to the Bumblebee).

This project investigated a novel approach for shape morphing by embedding a lightweight and electrical-driven artificial muscle called twisted-and-coiled actuators (TCAs) into a variable stiffness material that can switch between soft and rigid states when heated. A TCA can contract when electricity is applied and return to its original shape when electricity is removed. With the TCAs and the variable stiffness material, we can morph the shape of a robot's body made from them by softening the material, actuating the TCA to move the body to a new shape, and then rigidifying the material to maintain the new shape. To ensure the body can morph into a desired shape, we need to decide when to apply and apply how many voltages to TCAs. We address this question by establishing mathematical models based on the underlying physics to predict the shape change given a voltage applied to TCAs. We have also investigated how to directly use the change of the electrical resistance of TCAs, called self-sensing, to infer the shape change. With the models and the self-sensing, we have successfully developed a miniature shape morphing module that can bend and morph to a desired angle. Using the module, we have built several robotic systems that demonstrate how shape morphing can enhance the functionality of a robotic system. The first example is a gripper that can morph its palm to grasp objects with different sizes (from a glove to a cell phone). The second example is a quadrupedal robot that can use straight legs as flippers to swim in the water and bend the legs into a curved shape to walk on the ground. The research results generated from this project can pave the way for the next generation of transformable robots that can morph their body/leg shape on the fly, similar to how Bumblebee does, to actively adapt its functionality to the surrounding environments.

This project has provided research opportunities for multiple graduate and undergraduate students, and generated prototype demos (e.g., TCAs, shape morphing modules) for outreaching to K12 students through open houses and lab tours. The research results generated from this project, such as modeling and control of TCA-driven morphing modules, have been translated into undergraduate and graduate educational materials.
